sys_metadata_link.payload:
true
A service level agreement (SLA) defines the agreement and formal commitments between a service provider and a customer. The agreement documents the service to be provided or received, the agreed-upon service levels for the service, and the means of measuring or quantifying the level of service. The ability to resolve incidents in a specified time is a key part of delivering an agreed level of service.

Review and update SLA definitions and SLA properties based on the requirements within your organization.

]]>
false incident /contract_sla_list.do?sysparm_query=collection%3Dincident 3 1 false true SLA targets can be defined to monitor service level performance and to meet service level goals. These targets are defined using SLA definitions. Consider the following when setting up these definitions:Â 

Schedules

Schedules are typically based on the working hours of the resource or departments handling a task, in this case an incident. When defining an SLA, a schedule should be selected during which the SLA accumulates business time.

SLA Duration

If a schedule is selected in the SLA definition, the SLA duration works with the SLA schedule. For example, an SLA might have a user-specified duration of 16 hours with the schedule as 8-5 weekdays.

Workflow

SLA typically uses workflows to send notifications. SLA definitions should be updated with the correct workflows to send response and resolution notifications.

SLA Properties

Properties should be reviewed and configured based on the requirements within your organization.
